questions.text: You are assisting an ENT surgeon who places a cochlear implant into the scala tympani. Which part of the bone is the implant placed in?
questions.solution:
The implant is placed in the cochlea which is a part of the inner ear. The inner ear lies in the petrous part of the temporal bone.

The inner ear is well protected between the medial wall of the middle ear and the internal auditory canal.

questions.text: Where is the electrode placed in cochlear implant procedures?
questions.solution:
The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani. It allows for the electrodes to be in close proximity to the ganglion cells and their dendrites which are located in the modiolus and bony spiral lamina of the cochlea. 

A cochlear implant is an electronic device for severe to profound SNHL and who cannot benefit from a hearing aid. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the auditory nerve. Prerequisites include an intact cochlear nerve and higher auditory pathway.

In the auditory brainstem implant, the site of the implant is the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle. It is used when the cochlear nerve is not intact.

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: You are examining the CT scan images of the temporal bone of a patient. Which of the following structures can not be visualized on the CT scan?
questions.solution:
The organ of Corti present in the scala media is a part of the membranous labyrinth. It cannot be visualized on a CT scan.

Bony labyrinth consists of:

  • Vestibule
  • Cochlea
  • Semicircular canals

These structures can be seen on a CT scan of the temporal bone.

Membranous labyrinth consists of:

  • Saccule and utricle
  • Cochlear duct/ scala media
  • Semicircular ducts
  • Endolymphatic duct and sac

questions.text: The bony cochlea is a coiled tube making _____ turns around a bony pyramid called ____
questions.solution: The bony cochlea is a coiled tube making 2.5 to 2.75 turns round a central pyramid of bone called modiolus.

questions.text: Which two structures does the helicotrema connect?
questions.solution:
The scala vestibuli and scala tympani communicate with each other at the apex of the cochlea through an opening called the helicotrema.

Scala tympani and subarachnoid space are connected by the aqueduct of cochlea.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the bony cochlea?
questions.solution:
Scala media is part of the membranous cochlea.

The bony cochlea is a coiled tube with 2.5 to 2.75 turns around a central pyramid of bone called modiolus.

From the modiolus laterally into the tube winding like the thread of a screw is the osseous spiral lamina.

Spiral lamina along with membranes attached to it divide the tube into 3 parts:

  • Scala vestibuli above
  • Scala media in between
  • Scala tympani below.

The scala vestibule & tympani are part of the bony labyrinth and are filled with perilymph. They communicate with each other at the apex called helicotrema.

Scala media is part of the membranous cochlea and contains the sensory organ of Corti with hair cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the vestibule?

choices.text: It is a part of the membranous labyrinth
It is part of the auditory pathway

questions.solution:
Vestibule contains the spherical recess for the saccule.

It is part of the bony labyrinth and not part of the auditory pathway. The inside of the medial wall presents with recesses & openings:

  • A spherical recess, which lodges the saccule
  • An elliptical recess, which lodges the utricle
  • An opening for aqueduct of vestibule
  • An opening for the semicircular canals

questions.text: A patient has undergone a high-resolution CT of the temporal bone which confirmed a diagnosis of semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome. Which of the following will not be affected?
questions.solution:
The medial semicircular canal does not exist.

The semicircular canals are part of the bony labyrinth. They house the semicircular ducts which are the end organs for angular momentum.

They are 3 in number:

  • Superior also called anterior in the X-axis
  • Posterior in Y-axis
  • Lateral also called horizontal in Z-axis.

Semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome is an inner ear abnormality where the bony covering of the semicircular canals is very thin or absent. It usually affects the superior semicircular canal but can rarely involve the posterior or lateral semicircular canals. The superior semicircular canal is present inferior to the arcuate eminence of the temporal bone.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is the crus commune a part of?
questions.solution:
Crus commune is a part of the semicircular canals.

Each semicircular canal has 2 ends, ampullated & non-ampullated which open into the vestibule. The non-ampullated ends of posterior and superior canals unite to form a common channel called crus commune.

questions.text: A 45-year old construction worker presents to you with hearing loss. His audiogram reveals a diagnosis of noise-induced hearing loss. Which organ is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The organ of Corti is the sensory organ of hearing and is situated on the basilar membrane.

Chronic exposure to loud noises may mechanically damage the organ of Corti and result in noise induced hearing loss.

questions.text: The organ of Corti is situated over which membrane?
questions.solution:
The organ of Corti is situated over the basilar membrane in scala media.

The membranes of the cochlear duct:

  • The basilar membrane sepearates scala media from tympani and supports the organ of Corti.
  • Reissner’s membrane seperates scala media from scala vestibuli.
  • Stria vascularis is the lateral part of scala media which secretes endolymph.

Shrapnell’s membrane is another name for pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: What does the stria vascularis secrete?
questions.solution: The stria vascularis contains vascular epithelium and is concerned with secretion of endolymph.

questions.text: Where is the endolymph is seen?
questions.solution: Endolymph is present in the scala media.

questions.text: Which of the following fluids have high potassium and low sodium content?
questions.solution:
Endolymph is akin to intracellular fluid and hence high in potassium.

Perilymph and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) are both extracellular fluids (ECF) that are high in sodium.

Related Pearl: Inner ear fluids

  Perilymph Endolymph
Found in Bony labyrinth Membranous labyrinth
Similar to Extracellular fluid Intracellular fluid
Rich in Na+ ions K+ ions
Formation Filtrate of blood/ directly from CSF Produced by stria vascularis
Drainage Into CSF via cochlear aqueduct Absorbed through endolymphatic sac

questions.text: A 20-year-old man diagnosed with meningitis later develops sensorineural hearing loss. Which structure is responsible for the spread of his infection to the cochlea?
questions.solution: Infections can spread from the CNS to the inner ear or vice versa through the aqueduct of cochlea. Scala tympani is connected with the subarachnoid space through this structure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about membranous cochlea?

choices.text: Higher frequencies heard at the base
Lower frequencies are heard at the base
Higher frequencies are heard at the apex
All frequencies are heard at the apex

questions.solution:
Higher frequencies of sound are heard at the basal coil while lower frequencies are heard at the apical coil of membranous cochlea.

This is because the length of basilar membrane increases as we proceed from the basal coil to the apical coil.

questions.text: Which of the following sentence is false?

choices.text: Cristae are present in semicircular canal
Maculae are present in utricle and saccule
Organ of corti rests over basilar membrane
Reissner's membrane overlies the organ of Corti

questions.solution:
The tectorial membrane overlies the organ of Corti. Reissner's membrane separates scala vestibuli and scala media.

The basilar membrane supports the organ of Corti.

The sensory epithelium of the utricle and saccule is called macula and is concerned with linear acceleration and deceleration.

The ampullated end of each semicircular canal contains a thickened ridge of neuroepithelium called crista ampullaris.

Related Pearl: Sensory receptors in the inner ear

End Organ

Receptor

Action

Organ of Corti

Hair cells

Sound conduction

Ampulla of Semicircular ducts

Cristae

Angular momentum

Otolith organs: Utricle & saccule

Macula

Linear momentum

questions.text: Angular movements are sensed by
questions.solution:
Semicircular canals respond to angular acceleration and deceleration. The receptors are the cristae, located in the ampullated ends of the three semicircular ducts.

Their utricle and saccule which contain macula, are stimulated by linear acceleration and deceleration or gravitational pull during the head tilts.

questions.text: The endolymphatic duct is a continuation of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The endolymphatic duct is formed by the union of two ducts, one each from the saccule and the utricle.

Ductus reunions connect the cochlear duct to the saccule.

The aqueduct of cochlea (cochlear aqueduct) connects scala tympani to the subarachnoid space.

questions.text: Endolymphatic duct connects

choices.text: Scala vestibuli with aqueduct of cochlea

questions.solution:
The endolymphatic duct is formed by the union of two ducts, one each from the saccule and the utricle.

It passes through the vestibular aqueduct. Its terminal part is dilated to form an endolymphatic sac, which lies between the two layers of dura on the posterior surface of the petrous bone.

The scala vestibuli and scala tympani are filled with perilymph and communicate with each other at the apex of cochlea through an opening called helicotrema.

Aqueduct of cochlea connects scala tympani with subarachnoid space.

questions.text: Where is the endolymphatic sac is present?

choices.text: Subdural space in petrous part of temporal bone

questions.solution:
The terminal part of the endolymphatic duct is dilated to form an endolymphatic sac, which lies between the two layers of dura on the posterior surface of the petrous bone.

Endolymphatic sac is surgically important. It is exposed for drainage or shunt operation in Meniere’s disease.

questions.text: Blood supply to the labyrinth is from which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
Blood supply to the inner ear is by a branch of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery. 

The inner ear is supplied by labyrinthine artery, a branch of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, which is a branch of the basilar artery.
